Creating a comment¶

Companies can comment on any projects.
A comment cannot be posted on behalf of a company that does not belong to the authenticated user. This will result in a `HTTP 403 FORBIDDEN` error.

That being said, to create a comment, we use the HTTP `POST` method:

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/',
    type: 'POST',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    beforeSend: function (xhr) {
      xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    },
    data: {
      by_company: 1,
      on_project: 3,
      comment: "I like working with this company"
    },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});

Accessing all comments¶

In order to obtain an object of all comments, we use the HTTP `GET` method:

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/',
    type: 'GET',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    beforeSend: function (xhr) {
      xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});

Paginating a list of comments¶

By default, the API will return an object containing 3 comments, and will indicate the url to the next page.
For example, if we have 5 comments in total, then we’ll have 2 pages.
For obtaining the first 3, `http://localhost:8000/comments/` is enough.
To go to the last 2, we need to change page: `http://localhost:8000/comments/?page=2`

The default number of items per page can be set by changing the `PAGE_SIZE` setting in `settings.py`, under `REST_FRAMEWORK` options.

Filtering a list of comments¶

When listing companies, several filters can be applied:

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/',
    type: 'GET',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    // beforeSend: function (xhr) {
    //   xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    // },
    data: {
      by_company: 1, // Foreign key Integer
      on_project: 3 // Foreign key Integer
    },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});

Other filters will be added in a future release.

Accessing one specific comment¶

In order to access the data about a comment, we use also the HTTP `GET` method:

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/2/',
    type: 'GET',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    // beforeSend: function (xhr) {
    //   xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    // },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});

As you can notice here, the token section is commented out. That is because comments data can be accessed with or without being authenticated.

However, trying to achieve this for other operations will result in `HTTP 401 UNAUTHORIZED`

Updating a comment¶

To update a comment, we can use the HTTP `PUT` method.
This method requires that all the comment fields are sent. For less restrictive, use `PATCH` 

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/3/',
    type: 'PUT',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    beforeSend: function (xhr) {
      xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    },
    data: {
      by_company: 1,
      on_project: 5,
      comment: "I don't like working with this company"
    },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});

Deleting a comment¶

Take note that a comment can only be deleted if it was published by a company that belongs to the currently authenticated user.

In order to remove a comment, we use the HTTP `DELETE` method:

$.ajax({
    url: 'http://localhost:8000/comments/3/',
    type: 'DELETE',
    // Fetch the stored token from localStorage and set in the header
    beforeSend: function (xhr) {
      xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", 'Token '+ localStorage.getItem('token'));
    },
    success: function (response) {
      console.log(response);
    }
});
